reviews.review_msg: Val is a very solid prof. She gives a ton of feedback on the annotated bibliography to ensure you do well on the term paper. These two accumulate 40% of your grade, with the rest being participation + a presentation. The textbook is also ridiculously easy to follow along with and read. Would recommend.

I like Dr. Parent as a person, but I don't regard him highly as a professor. I'm not someone who thinks memorizing a textbook passes for an education. The textbook is awful. The midterm exam is worth 35%, while the final is also worth 35%. So that's 70% based on exams. The questions on the exams are random (so memorize everything!)

By far one of the best classes I have ever taken at SFU. Amazing guest speakers almost every week and an incredible wealth of knowledge for those looking for a career in the criminal justice field. Show up to class and pay attention and you will do well and get lots out of it!

The MC section of his exams are fairly doable if you read the textbook. The written part of the exam is what kills ya. He has so many guest speakers throughout the semester and assigns a bunch of random articles as well. Make sure you know every little thing because chances are he will probably ask you it on the exam.

Rick's a GREAT prof once you get to the 300 level courses. I had the same complaints when he was teaching me 251, but trust me, it gets better. Also, one of the best lecturer's I know. Keeps it informal and gives relevant hints to what is on the exams. If you've declared your major and are in 3rd year, take his class. I can't recommend him enough.

Best prof for policing.  Very knowledgeable, lots of experience and very funny.  Tells great stories and doesn't sugar coat policing like many recruiters.  If your interested in policing or how it works great class and prof to take.  Work load is decent and he is very fair.
Funny guy until I saw my final grade.. hahaha what a joke of a terrible grade. Don't take him, go to a comedy show instead and save your GPA

If you take a class by Shchitov, prepare to read the text book and teach yourself. When he teaches, he goes off topic. That accent of his makes it difficult to understand him too. As for the papers, he doesnt lay out criteria for them. Exams wise, he takes from the review questions of the textbook and his own review questions for lecture slides.

He goes off topic quite often that you will find yourself not being able to follow his words every lecture time. So I did not find his lecture nor interesting or helpful. He seems a hard marker with no specific criteria especially for papers.

- enthusiastic, approachable, funny and caring - passionate about course material - quick to mark assingments - facilitates good discussions on lectures could be improved: - reduce length of articles (100 pages is unrealistic to read)

LOVED Josh's classes. His passion for the subject matter rubs off on his students, and he is always available for extra help on papers, etc. He's a tough marker, but he's fair. Discussion in these classes were some of the best I've had in 6 years of attendance at SFU. I took 351 based on how awesome 251 with him was and was delighted. A fresh take.
